subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Names and rerunning Test instances for Parameterized Tests
msgSnippet: #: Eugene Kuleshov changed the world a bit at a time by saying on  10/19/2005 10:32 PM :# ... Any suggestions are appreciated. We have tried to keep it in the
messageBody:
#: Eugene Kuleshov changed the world a bit at a time by saying on 10/19/2005 10:32 PM :#
> CÃ©dric Beust ? wrote:
>
>>>From this point of view the
>>>approach Cedric choose for TestNG is less intrusive (even so I hate
>>>xml configs and believe that he should of provided an API for IDE
>>>integration and embedding instead of generating temporary xml configs
>>>from an IDE plugins)
>>>
>>>
>>The API exists and is used in many places. Running TestNG programmatically
>>is as simple as
>>
>>TestNG tng = new TestNG();
>>tng.addTestClass(...);
>>tng.addListener(...);
>>tng.run();
>>
>>Generating a temporary XML file in the Eclipse and IDEA plug-ins is a choice
>>made by their respective authors, and it has pros and cons.
>>
>>Either way, I'm not sure how this implementation detail impacts the user...
>>Did this cause you any trouble?
>>
>>
> I knew you'd respond... Anyway, it does not cause me any trouble
> except responding to your comments, because I don't use TestNG. I guess
> this is mostly because I like existing tools for junit much better
> (especially look of the reports I get from ant tasks, cc build and few
> others)... If I'll have to write another plugin for Eclipse to run
> TestNG, because look of the current one hurt my eyes. :-)
>

Any suggestions are appreciated. We have tried to keep it in the same line as JUnit plugin.

> By the way, did anyone bothered to check the temporary directory after
> long time of using TestNG?

Temporary directory? The plugin does nothing there. The temp files are created in the project
directory (or a better option I have in mind is to move them in the output dir). However I don't
think this is a real worry as way to many software are using this solution (take Idea, Acrobat
Reader, etc. as examples).

> After all, don't you think that it is much slower to create temporary
> file, especially when you don't really need it?

If somebody comes out with an example where this file writting is increasing the execution time
innexplicably I will try to find out some other solution immediately.

> I'd understand if you
> would have an action to copy such xml to the clipboard, so one can paste
> it into email or issue tracker...
>

You can save it for later tests or don't know, submit it to your friend to redo the exactly test you
have run.

cheers,

./alex
--
.w( the_mindstorm )p.


> regards,
> Eugene
